subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Abbots Morton Experiment update
msgSnippet: Thanks for all the hard work - from one who knows.    I created the late unlamented QSJ Block, a QuikScript Junior TTF. After creating the letterforms,
messageBody:
Thanks for all the hard work - from one who knows.
   I created the late unlamented QSJ Block, a QuikScript Junior TTF. After creating the letterforms, I tried to learn how to create kerning pairs. There was next to no help available for this at the time, and I couldn't even start to correct the fundamental problems and had no way to reduce the job from a combinatorial explosion of pairs of characters. I had to drop it at the end; I always hoped someone would pick it up since I did like the letter shapes.

From: Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...>
To: "Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, June 29, 2013 3:21 PM
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Abbots Morton Experiment update



If you've been reading my blog you've probably noticed some me blathering on about a font called "Abbots Morton Experiment". While it's still very much a work in progress, I'm happy to announce that it's ready to be mentioned here explicitly. Abbots Morton Experiment is a Quikscript font designed to use the capabilities of contemporary OpenType font renderers, and uses features like kerning pairs and contextual alternates to deliver Senior Quikscript capabilities using computer typesetting. It uses the usual code points in the Private Use Area.

If you'd like to see it in action, there's both my blog and a special build of The Call of Cthulhu using Abbots Morton Experiment in place of Kingsley.

At this point I'd describe it as beta software — I'm not about to use it for the Quikscript Literature series just yet. I'm announcing it here because at this point it'd likely be improved faster if I had others pointing out where I should focus my attention. If you're seeing what it's like, keep in mind:

  • The source text for Call of Cthulhu uses standard parentheses (U+0028 & 9) instead of angled parentheses (U+E66E & F). It also uses straight quotes and no prime marks; I'll fix all those things once AME is ready to be used there.
  • .PeaHalf.Roe exists (I put it in early as a proof-of-concept), but it needs work.

Of course, any and all feedback would be more than welcome. The next thing I need to do is figure out what kerning groups there should be, and then kern what can be kerned (and not kern what doesn't need to be). Beyond that, alternate letterforms would be handy — I want to have .See.Key look like it's made with one stroke just like .Utter.Roe does.
